sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In this paper we prove versions of this result for bad reduction types in families of curves over the rational numbers. More precisely, we show that the primes of bad semistable reduction obey an Erdős–Kac type theorem in certain universal families.

sec.title: Theorem

list-item.p: Over the set of hyperelliptic curves of fixed genus, the (renormalised) number of primes of bad semistable reduction is normally distributed.
Over the set of plane curves of fixed degree, the (renormalised) number of primes of bad semistable reduction is normally distributed.

sec.title: Motivation
An Erdős–Kac type result
sec.p: We prove an Erdős–Kac type theorem as an application of the main result of [7]. We begin by recalling the set up of [7, Thm. 1.8].

sec.p: The rest of our results are based on the following simple application of Theorem 2.1.

Remark 3.2
sec.p: Theorem 2.1 also gives versions of Theorem 3.1 for projective space instead of affine space. The corresponding effective equidistribution property is proven in [12, Prop. 2.1].

sec.title: Corollary 3.3
Semistable reduction
sec.p: We recall some basic properties of semistable curves and Jacobians [16, Tag 0E6X]. Another good reference is [11, §8-10], but the definitions there are slightly different.

sec.title: Definition 4.1
sec.p: We say C has bad reduction at p if it does not have good reduction at p.

sec.p: As an example, we apply this to the family of all hyperelliptic curves.

Remark 5.6
sec.p: See [3, eq. (10)] for examples where Theorem 5.4 applies but Theorem 5.2 does not.

For families of Jacobians with everywhere potentially good reduction, the hypotheses of Theorems 5.2 and 5.4 are evidently not satisfied: if J has potentially good reduction at p, then it cannot have bad semistable reduction at p.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Robert Lemke Oliver is supported by the National Science Foundation grant DMS-2200760 and by a Simons Fellowship in Mathematics. Daniel Loughran is supported by UKRI Future Leaders Fellowship MR/V021362/1. Ari Shnidman was funded by the European Union (ERC, CurveArithmetic, 101078157) and the Israel Science Foundation (grant No. 2301/20).

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: All authors provided equal contributions to the article.

notes.title: Conflict of interest
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
